prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width of our targets is FWHM=500 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s to resolve the line profiles. As such we ask for FDM mode with 1.875GHz bandwidth and x16 frequency binning to keep the data load at a minimum. This typically results in a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. The data will be binned to lower resolution depending on the targets FWHM and signal to noise ratio.

Our targets have expected source sizes of order 1-2''. As we only aim to measure the total flux of each line in each object we ask for the most compact array configuration, C34-1 or C34-2, in order to keep the phase stability at its maximum.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by the scientific goal to detect CO lines out to redshift z~6 and to detect the weaker CI(1-0) line at z=3.3~4.8 which breaks many redshift ambiguities. Based on our continuum observations we can calculate a dust mass for these sources which we use to get an integrated CO(1-0) intensity (assuming a gas-to-dust-ratio of 100 and a CO conversion factor of X_CO=0.8 M_sun/K km/s pc^2). By using a CO excitation model we calculate a minimum line peak intensity of ~ 8 mJy for sources at redshift z~6, which matches our observations well, see Figure 1 of the Scientific Justification. To achieve a 5 sigma detection in several individual channels even at these extreme redshifts we aim for an RMS level of 1.5 m at 100 km/s which is sufficiently to sample the line shape.

The line width of our targets is FWHM=500 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s to resolve the line profiles. As such we ask for FDM mode with 1.875GHz bandwidth and x16 frequency binning to keep the data load at a minimum. This typically results in a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. The data will be binned to lower resolution depending on the targets FWHM and signal to noise ratio.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by the scientific goal to detect CO lines out to redshift z~6 and to detect the weaker CI(1-0) line at z=3.3~4.8 which breaks many redshift ambiguities. Based on our continuum observations we can calculate a dust mass for these sources which we use to get an integrated CO(1-0) intensity (assuming a gas-to-dust-ratio of 100 and a CO conversion factor of X_CO=0.8 M_sun/K km/s pc^2). By using a CO excitation model we calculate a minimum line peak intensity of ~ 8 mJy for sources at redshift z~6, which matches our observations well, see Figure 1 of the Scientific Justification. To achieve a 5 sigma detection in several individual channels even at these extreme redshifts we aim for an RMS level of 1.5 m at 100 km/s which is sufficiently to sample the line shape.

The line width of our targets is FWHM=500 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 100 km/s to resolve the line profiles. As such we ask for FDM mode with 1.875GHz bandwidth and x16 frequency binning to keep the data load at a minimum. This typically results in a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. The data will be binned to lower resolution depending on the targets FWHM and signal to noise ratio.

Our targets have expected source sizes of order 1-2''. As we only aim to measure the total flux of each line in each object we ask for the most compact array configuration, C34-1 or C34-2, in order to keep the phase stability at its maximum.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by the scientific goal to detect CO lines out to redshift z~6 and to detect the weaker CI(1-0) line at z=3.3~4.8 which breaks many redshift ambiguities. Based on our continuum observations we can calculate a dust mass for these sources which we use to get an integrated CO(1-0) intensity (assuming a gas-to-dust-ratio of 100 and a CO conversion factor of X_CO=0.8 M_sun/K km/s pc^2). By using a CO excitation model we calculate a minimum line peak intensity of ~ 8 mJy for sources at redshift z~6, which matches our observations well, see Figure 1 of the Scientific Justification. To achieve a 5 sigma detection in several individual channels even at these extreme redshifts we aim for an RMS level of 1.5 m at 100 km/s which is sufficiently to sample the line shape.

The main aim of this science goal is to obtain spatially resolved images of the dust continuum emission. However, in our Cycle 0 data, we serendipitously detected a spectral feature in ~10% of the sources we observed (see, e.g., Spilker et al. 2014). In some cases, these serendipitous line detections can break ambiguities in the redshift determination, so we configure the spectral averaging in the correlator to allow for any serendipitous line detections to be spectrally resolved over multiple (5-15) velocity bins. This leads to a spectral resolution of 30km/s. The basebands are aligned to create two gap-free sidebands of 3.75GHz each. With our 7.5 GHz of spectral coverage, we estimate from our source redshift distribution and experience in Cycle 0 that there is a reasonable chance that we will blindly detect lines in ~3 objects.

From the similar high resolution imaging obtained in cycle 0 we know that our sources have a source size of 1-2.5 arcsec. Since the sources in this proposal is picked from the same source sample as the cycle 0 sample we assume that the sources will be of similar sizes. We use 3 arcsec as the limit on the largest angular structure to be sure to that we will get the largest structures in our sources even if a few of them turn out to be slightly larger than what we observed in cycle 0. With the resolution of 0.5 arcsec used in cycle 0 we had a few sources that were not fully resolved. To create lens models and calculate magnifications for such sources we need resolve them better and we therefore request a moderately higher resolution of 0.3 arcsec in this cycle.

From 870 micron unresolved LABOCA fluxes of our targets we know that the total flux of our sources in this band is 20-150 mJy. The lower flux limit in this proposal is slightly lower than in cycle 0 meaning that the faintest sources are potentially a bit fainter than what we have already observed. In this cycle we ask for a slightly higher angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec compared to 0.5 arcsec for cycle 0 based on experiences from that run (see the justification for the angular resolution). For our observations in cycle 0 we made detailed calculations estimating a minimum flux of 1.6mJy within one beam for our faintest structures. We requested an rms of 0.4 mJy over 7.5 GHz (split over two arrays of 0.57 mJy each) which was sufficient to study their resolved structure. Taking the lower flux limit and the slightly higher resolution into account we use our experiences and calculations from cycle 0 to calculate a wanted rms of 0.15 mJy over 7.5 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Field SPT0112-55 + Field SPT0155-62, Imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Field SPT0112-55 and Field SPT0155-62 combined, SPT0147-64 has been taken out to make this possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main aim of this science goal is to obtain spatially resolved images of the dust continuum emission. However, in our Cycle 0 data, we serendipitously detected a spectral feature in ~10% of the sources we observed (see, e.g., Spilker et al. 2014). In some cases, these serendipitous line detections can break ambiguities in the redshift determination, so we configure the spectral averaging in the correlator to allow for any serendipitous line detections to be spectrally resolved over multiple (5-15) velocity bins. This leads to a spectral resolution of 30km/s. The basebands are aligned to create two gap-free sidebands of 3.75GHz each. With our 7.5 GHz of spectral coverage, we estimate from our source redshift distribution and experience in Cycle 0 that there is a reasonable chance that we will blindly detect lines in ~3 objects.

From the similar high resolution imaging obtained in cycle 0 we know that our sources have a source size of 1-2.5 arcsec. Since the sources in this proposal is picked from the same source sample as the cycle 0 sample we assume that the sources will be of similar sizes. We use 3 arcsec as the limit on the largest angular structure to be sure to that we will get the largest structures in our sources even if a few of them turn out to be slightly larger than what we observed in cycle 0. With the resolution of 0.5 arcsec used in cycle 0 we had a few sources that were not fully resolved. To create lens models and calculate magnifications for such sources we need resolve them better and we therefore request a moderately higher resolution of 0.3 arcsec in this cycle.

From 870 micron unresolved LABOCA fluxes of our targets we know that the total flux of our sources in this band is 20-150 mJy. The lower flux limit in this proposal is slightly lower than in cycle 0 meaning that the faintest sources are potentially a bit fainter than what we have already observed. In this cycle we ask for a slightly higher angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec compared to 0.5 arcsec for cycle 0 based on experiences from that run (see the justification for the angular resolution). For our observations in cycle 0 we made detailed calculations estimating a minimum flux of 1.6mJy within one beam for our faintest structures. We requested an rms of 0.4 mJy over 7.5 GHz (split over two arrays of 0.57 mJy each) which was sufficient to study their resolved structure. Taking the lower flux limit and the slightly higher resolution into account we use our experiences and calculations from cycle 0 to calculate a wanted rms of 0.15 mJy over 7.5 GHz.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
In Cycle 0 and 1 we performed unbiased redshift surveys in the 3mm band of 39 sources from the SPT sample. These programs were great successes yielding 31 secure redshifts and 5 single line detections. The galaxies in our sample have a mean redshift of z~3.5 with the record holder at z=5.8. The high mean redshift compared to other samples is mainly due to the unique selection wavelength of 1.4mm of the SPT survey and the aid of strong lensing.
We use the unique redshift selection function of the SPT sample to identify the most distant and extreme dusty starbursts in the Universe and propose to obtain redshifts (via scans of the 3mm band) and lens magnifications (via high-spatial-resolution 870micron continuum imaging) for the 8 reddest (and thus likely most distant) sources from the SPT sample. With only a 15% increase of observing time we will cover 19 more SPT sources in the same observing setup located in the same fields. With this data we will probe the frequency of occurrence of massive starbursts at extreme redshifts (z=5-7) which will put tight constraints on semi-analytic galaxy formation models and nearly double the number of SPT sources with redshifts and lens models.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00957.S, The ALMA-SPT Redshift Survey, Axel Weiss 2011.0.00958.S, Imaging the Brightest Starbursts in the Universe, Dan Marrone 2012.1.00844.S, CO redshifts of SPT sources, Axel Weiss
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
